title: ASX slides lower as miners, banks retreat; Tesla slumps
text:
The Australian sharemarket has made a poor start after a mixed session on Wall Street as gains for Alphabet and artificial-intelligence stocks helped make up for Tesla’s steep tumble.

The ASX 200 was 48 points, or 0.5 per cent, lower to 8661.2 at 11.20am AEST, with nine of 11 industry sectors in negative territory.

Wall Street is digesting a series of results from high-profile companies. Credit: Bloomberg

Mining stocks weighed heavily on the bourse as their recent rally lost steam, with heavyweights Rio Tinto and BHP each losing 1.7 per cent in early trade, while Fortescue shed 2.1 per cent.

Energy stocks rose as oil prices strengthened. Woodside rose 2 per cent and Santos added 0.7 per cent.

title: Who hasn’t cheated? I have. So why do we mock the Coldplaygate couple?
text:
Hands up, anyone who has never cheated in their life. At cards, on someone, whatever. Not many. Yeah, that checks out. Because we’re human. Born to stuff up.

My hand is down. I’ve been a cheater. The guilt I carried is gone, replaced by regret and gratitude that I learned a lot about the world and myself. And that I could absorb those lessons in private.

Then-chief executive of Astronomer, Andy Byron, and the company’s chief people officer, Kirstin Cabot, at the Coldplay concert. Credit: Aresna Villanueva

It takes time to admit you did something shithouse. To work out what got you there, and no, the answer is rarely too many cocktails. That’s probably just the tipping point. You need to go deep, be super honest.

Which is why the global infamy of Jumbotrongate – the Astronomer colleagues Andy Byron and Kristin Cabot caught hugging on the big screen at a Coldplay concert – has made me reflect. Sure, and be briefly obsessed. I’m not nearly that good a person that I can’t relish a gotcha moment.

title: Driver stumped by 'insane' parking sign in Aussie city: 'Good luck'
text:
The parking sign in the affluent Sydney suburb is going viral and dividing drivers. Can you understand it?

It's well talked about how it is becoming increasingly more difficult to find parking in built-up areas across Australia's major cities. But even when drivers do nab a spot, it can sometimes be hard to decipher the complex parking rules that govern inner-metro streets

That appeared to be the case for one Sydney driver this week, who was caught on camera staring in a prolonged state up at a parking sign with no less than five different instructions and an array of differing times. A fellow driver in Paddington spotted the woman seeming to be utterly confused, and admitted she too was lost trying to understand the instructions.

The driver joked she was sending "thoughts and prayers" to woman.

"I don't blame you love, because someone tell me what that means," she said in a a clip that has been watched more than 330,000 times in about 24 hours.

ADVERTISEMENT

The viral clip ultimately sparked a mixed reaction online with some claiming the instructions were straightforward while others were a little less sure.

*Answer at the bottom.

Aussies say 'yeah, nah' to complicated parking sign

Australian drivers flooded the comments section admitting they too were perplexed by the instructions.

"Absolutely not, I'm parking somewhere else. All I'm seeing is that you're going to cop a fine," one person said, while another called the sign "unnecessarily complicated". A third simply said, "yeah, nah" to the whole thing.

However many others claimed to know exactly what the sign was trying to communicate, and argued anyone who couldn't piece it together "shouldn't be driving".

"There's nothing complicated about this. It make sense," one woman claimed, while another driver called it "very easy to read".

ADVERTISEMENT

Parking instructions decoded

The parking sign details the spot to the left of the pole is a loading zone between 8am and 10.30am everyday, but then changes to two-hour ticketed parking between 10.30 am and 4 pm, and between 7 and 9pm, Monday to Friday. During 4pm to 7pm on weekdays there is no parking as a bus lane operates. On the weekends, two-hour ticketed parking is allowed between 10.30am and 9pm.

In 2022, Sydney trialled digital road signs in a bid to make parking instructions easier to understand for drivers. However, they were not widely adopted.

*Answer: No, it's a loading zone.
